urn:contentItem:64F0-TS21-JD34-V1GH-00000-00Influx of sea-changers, 'complacency' prompt fire danger warnings2022-01-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:04:42ZLexisNexisSATURDAYInflux of sea-changers, 'complacency' prompt fire danger warningsJessica Greenan

As 15,000 tourists converge on Warrnambool this summer, fire agencies are warning of heightened risk and urged residents to guard against complacency.

With severe heat wave conditions predicted over the New Year period, CFA chief officer Jason Heffernan urged sea-changers heading to the regions to stay updated on fire conditions.

"A wet winter and spring is now behind us and December has been very dry in large parts of Victoria," he said.

"On hot, dry and windy days like the ones we are expecting this weekend, anyone in regional areas of Victoria needs to stay alert to conditions.

"For anyone planning to travel this weekend, it's really important to make sure you know which fire weather district you will be in and travel through.

"You also need to look at the fire danger ratings daily and if it is severe, reconsider your need to travel. Don't travel to areas with an extreme or code red fire danger rating."

IN OTHER NEWS:

Coastal land sale opens door for housing estate

Rates are on the rise again next year

Community stalwart farewelled

Town bounces back after tough run

Can speedway's new year's day specialist o it again?

Forest Fire Victoria spokesman Rod Incoll said holiday-makers posed one of the greatest dangers to regional Victoria including coastal areas like Warrnambool.

"Holiday-makers are one of the greatest hazards because they normally come from an urban area, so often they're basically not fire-wise," he said.

"Most of the country people have some idea of what to do to keep fires safe and when to light them and when not to light them.

"There will be plenty of days in which we can get fires running, it doesn't need to be a big fire that takes a lot of houses - even a small fire that starts in scrub could be quite traumatic for people camping in the area and can destroy their assets."

He said he feared Warrnambool's relatively small history of large-scale bushfires had the potential to also create complacency.

"The fact that there have not been many fire or injuries on the record leads to complacency," he said.

"All you need for a fire is dry fuel and an ignition source.

"Anywhere there's vegetation like coastal scrub is particularly hazardous, especially when you get people who aren't fire-wise who think nothing of having a campfire and then walking away and leaving the site or go to bed in their tent and leave the fire running without ensuring the safety of their fire.

"There's a lot of small stuff that can lead to big stuff."

urn:contentItem:61TN-B9M1-F0J6-J01V-00000-00Take care in the Grampians2021-01-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:04:41ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 9Take care in the Grampians

With thousands of Victorians expected to make the most of the Australia Day weekend by exploring parks, forests and reserves, Forest Fire Management Victoria is asking visitors to plan ahead and enjoy their trip.

FFMVic Grampians deputy chief fire officer Tony English said whether you're camping, walking, riding, or driving, the Australia Day weekend was a great opportunity to discover our beautiful parks, forests and reserves.

"We want people to enjoy our forests, follow the rules by knowing what they can and can't do and set a good example by behaving responsibly," he said.

"Authorised officers will partner with other agencies including Victoria Police to patrol areas so everyone can have a safe and enjoyable weekend. It's the middle of summer, so if it's hot or windy, use common sense and don't light a campfire and if you do have a campfire, it must be fully extinguished with water, not soil, and must be cool to touch before being safe to leave."

Mr English said said people were urged to be careful, especially when it comes to campfires, as gusty winds would easily carry embers from a campfire and into the bush.

"...People should monitor the situation via the various information channels available including their local radio stations or the Vic Emergency Line on free call 1800 226 226 or download the Vic Emergency app," he said.

For more information on campfire safety rules and forest regulations, visit https://www.ffm.vic.gov.au/permits-and-regulations/fire-restrictions-and-regulations.

urn:contentItem:635C-VN21-F0J6-J23R-00000-00Remembering city blaze2021-07-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:04:41ZLexisNexisRemembering city blazeAlex Blain and Alex Dalziel

Fifty years ago, the workers from Horsham's newly opened State government offices wandered through the blackened shell of their headquarters.

Just hours before, on Saturday, July 17, 1971, the building had been engulfed in flames, explosions tearing through it after a welding accident set the building alight.

Then-head of the Forests Commission, Jack Gillespie, which sat at the rear of the building on the third floor, recounted his experience to the Mail-Times in 2009.

As head of a department, Mr Gillespie was one of the first people allowed back into the building after the fire.

According to Mr Gillespie, the fire had gutted the building, the damage devastating.

'The top floor was ruined, and the land officer draftsman's records, which were up to 50 years old, were saturated. - Jack Gillespie in 2009. Mr Gillespie had been at home making lunch for his two children when he heard the State government building was alight. The fire was already burning fiercely when he arrived on the scene.

''Firefighters were on the roof of the SEC building and the post office trying to reach the fire, and there was a river of water gushing down the stairs the whole time,'' he said.

''I was up throughout the afternoon talking to the regional officer as to how the fire was going; did they need anything? We had hoses and pumps for forest fire fighting, but no-one was on weekend duty because it wasn't yet summer, and we couldn't get them.''

It wasn't until after the fire had been put out that the true extent of the damage was revealed.

''The top floor was ruined, and the land officer draftsman's records, which were up to 50 years old, were saturated,'' he said.

''The Agriculture Department lost every scrap of paper relating to the activities of the department over a great length of time. And all the plans in the Lands Department, which were highly valuable, were soaked.

"They were stored in horizontal wooden drawers which filled with water. Luckily for our department, we had recently moved a lot of our plans out of a similar system into a vertical metal cabinet, which didn't allow for the accumulation of water.''

urn:contentItem:62V1-4K71-JD34-V3Y6-00000-00How could $250K be spent on Buckland Valley sites? Have your say2021-06-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:04:41ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8How could $250K be spent on Buckland Valley sites? Have your sayEllen Ebsary

New facilities are proposed for camping and day visitor areas in the Buckland Valley with planners seeking community feedback.

A draft master plan has been developed by the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning (DELWP) in collaboration with Taungurung Land and Waters Council and other land managers.

It will inform a $250,000 investment in upgrades to attract more visitors as part of the Victoria's Great Outdoors initiative.

Short walks with high goldfields interpretation, more toilet facilities and river access are among additions proposed.

The various horse riding individuals and representatives of a range of groups, including Diann Talbot, have been among those residents and users guiding the plan's development.

The Hall and Lumsden families provided important land-use insights and Fred Sargent supplied up-to-date information on key mining localities.

The Buckland Bridge picnic area is the only formal picnic spot with opportunities identified.

The creation of specific tracks for recreational four-wheel driving is not identified in the plan's scope but it's anticipated new facilities will encourage four-wheel drivers to stay longer.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Hume deputy chief fire officer Aaron Kennedy said feedback was needed on the draft plan.

IN OTHER NEWS:

Regional Victorians won't qualify for $500 payment in this lockdown Border nurses left stressed snub pay offer 21 thefts from cars reported in Wodonga in just one week "We received 425 responses to a community survey last year which outlined that people want more walking, riding and horse trails to connect between key sites," he said.

"We also heard that people want more interpretive signage to outline the cultural significance of important sites and day visitor facilities upgraded.

"We are now seeking feedback on the proposed works outlined in the draft master plan."

For more information and to provide feedback please go to: https://engage.vic.gov.au/buckland-valley-state-forest-recreation-master-plan.

Consultation closes on Monday, June 14.

urn:contentItem:61K2-59D1-F0J6-J2NN-00000-00More slashing, mowing due soon in battle against rapid grass growth2020-12-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:04:41ZLexisNexisMore slashing, mowing due soon in battle against rapid grass growthElspeth Kernebone

FIRE protection works are continuing across 2000 acres of public land in central Victoria, as agencies battle rapid grass growth.

The Forest Fire Management Victoria preparations across the Murray Goldfields District include slashing and moving public land.

FFMVic district manager Adrian Parker said recent spring rain had caused quick grass growth throughout the area.

Other news:

Man who allegedly robbed Long Gully service station fronts court And the winner of the 2020 Christmas lights competition is ... Soulsby smashes shot put records in AV Shield He said FFMVic had begun its preparations in the northern part of the district, where grass was cured, working its way south as conditions became suitable.

Mr Parker said crews were preparing across about 800 locations in publish land, to date they included areas near Bendigo, Castlemaine, Healthcote, Maryborough and Macedon.

He said works would continue this week near Bendigo, Huntly, Flora Hill, Golden Square, Ironbark, Castlemaine and Macedon.

Mr Parker said mechanical treatments such as slashing and mowing were an effective way to reduce the spread and intensity of bushfires, helping fire fighters to control blazes.

He urged people to prepare their own property against bushfire.

Find out more about bushfire preparation on the Country Fire Authority website: cfa.vic.gov.au/plan-prepare

urn:contentItem:63FP-PYF1-F0J6-J14D-00000-00Parts of Wombat Forest to reopen soon2021-08-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:04:41ZLexisNexisParts of Wombat Forest to reopen soonHayley Elg

Parts of the Wombat State Forest will soon reopen to the public after weeks of efforts to clean-up the area after a wild storm swept through the region in June.

Forest Fire Management Victoria have now assessed all of the impacted strategic fire access roads, with about 43 per cent of those roads now cleared.

FFMVic expects this figure to increase during the next five days, with crews to use heavy machinery to remove hazardous trees.

It comes after a ferocious storm ravaged parts of Victoria on June 10, including through the Wombat State Forest, causing hundreds of trees to fall and leaving many residents in towns such as Trentham and Blackwood without power for days.

Some areas of the forest have not yet been cleared due to access issues, seasonal road closures and bad weather.

After further assessments for safety risks and work to address hazardous trees, some areas of the forest will soon be reopened to allow the community to collect firewood, along with some recreational sites.

Grampians Deputy Chief Fire Officer, Tony English, said FFMVic was finalising plans to open parts of the forest.

"Since the storm, our crews have been completing hazardous tree works and stabilising impacted roads and tracks, including allowing access to some designated firewood collection areas from 1 September 2021," he said.

Closures have been in place to protect the community from the continued risk of hazardous trees and due to the movement of heavy machinery conducting clean-up works.

Even when parts of the forest do shortly open, the 'public safety zone' will remain in place and some areas will remain closed.

This is because of ongoing public safety concerns due to the risk of falling trees and as crews will be completing 'critical work' with plant and heavy machinery.

FFMVic stressed the importance of adhering to closures, both for personal safety and to allow crews to operate safely and effectively.

Mr English thanked the community for being patient while the clean-up continued.

Further updates will be provided as more recreation sites reopen.

urn:contentItem:6558-6S01-JD34-V3GD-00000-00Baiting no solution to foxes: MP2022-04-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:04:41ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 9Baiting no solution to foxes: MPCaleb Cluff

The sole representative of the Shooters, Fishers and Farmers Party in state parliament says the laying of 1080 fox and vermin bait by the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning in the weeks before duck hunting season leads to more animals being shot.

Jeff Bourmann, who represents Eastern Victoria in the Legislative Council, says the timing of DELWP's decision to use the baits just before the hunting season opens is suspect.

"The timing seems to be very suspect around state game reserves, because they could do it a month earlier, or a month after the season or something like that," Mr Bourmann says.

"The effect on people's dogs would then be basically zero. But they're doing it a week before the season, so there's a lot of people that will quite rightly not take their dog with them, and that will actually lead to more ducks being shot, because the people won't be able to retrieve as many ducks."

Mr Bourmann says using hunters to help reduce fox and feral numbers in state parks and reserves has been raised by his party "time and time again."

"It goes into the deep black hole that is DELWP and commonsense - and you may quote me on that," Mr Bourmann says.

"The problem is there's a lot of people in DELWP that are proper environmentalists; they know the best way of getting rid of these pest animals is with a gun and not laying waste to the countryside with poison. But then there's some committed greenie types who are just opposed to hunting. So it just ends up being a disaster area. And it's all the other animals that basically pay the price."

A spokesperson for Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMVic) said the agency had been laying baits in Mt Hooghly, Bung Bong and Wareek state forests, to reduce the number of foxes in the area, which prey on nearby livestock as well as native species.

"Risk assessments are undertaken to guide the timing of baiting activities, baiting locations and the placement of baits to ensure there is minimal impact on native animals and other non-target species. Baiting is conducted by a qualified and experienced controller," the spokesperson said.

"Fox baits are buried to a specified depth according to Victorian Directions for Use and manufacturer's guidelines to reduce risks to native animals, which are generally unlikely to uncover buried baits."

The department says 1080 (sodium fluoroacetate) is registered and approved by the Australian Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority (APVMA) for the control of a variety of pest animals in Victoria.

The use of 1080 baits is only one element of pest animal management and is used as part of an integrated pest animal control program. Integrated pest animal control requires planning, the use of a range of control tools and is best achieved with cooperation from adjoining land managers.

FFMVic Senior Forest Manager and Roading Officer, Lynda Mabon said the baiting program will run until 30 May 2022.

"Foxes are a pest animal in Australia and attack livestock and wildlife. Every year, foxes are responsible for significant stock losses, especially during lambing season," Ms Mabon said.

"Foxes are also known to carry diseases and increase the spread of weeds in our state forests."

Ms Mabon said baits containing 1080 poison would be buried in bait stations in the program areas, with baits monitored regularly and replaced weekly. The baits will be removed at the end of the program.

"Baits are buried in bait stations according to strict guidelines that minimise the risk of other species taking them," she said.

"These baits could pose a risk to domestic animals and we ask nearby landholders to ensure their dogs and other pets are confined to their property.

"Neighbouring landowners have been notified of the program and signs have been placed at entrances to the control areas so that visitors are aware of the baiting."

Under the Catchment and Land Protection Act 1994, foxes are declared pests.

urn:contentItem:634Y-XC11-F0J6-J2GM-00000-00Remembering city blaze2021-07-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:04:42ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Remembering city blazeAlex Blain and Alex Dalziel

Fifty years ago, the workers from Horsham's newly opened State government offices wandered through the blackened shell of their headquarters.

Just hours before, on Saturday, July 17, 1971, the building had been engulfed in flames, explosions tearing through it after a welding accident set the building alight.

Then-head of the Forests Commission, Jack Gillespie, which sat at the rear of the building on the third floor, recounted his experience to the Mail-Times in 2009.

As head of a department, Mr Gillespie was one of the first people allowed back into the building after the fire.

According to Mr Gillespie, the fire had gutted the building, the damage devastating.

'The top floor was ruined, and the land officer draftsman's records, which were up to 50 years old, were saturated. - Jack Gillespie in 2009. Mr Gillespie had been at home making lunch for his two children when he heard the State government building was alight. The fire was already burning fiercely when he arrived on the scene.

''Firefighters were on the roof of the SEC building and the post office trying to reach the fire, and there was a river of water gushing down the stairs the whole time,'' he said.

''I was up throughout the afternoon talking to the regional officer as to how the fire was going; did they need anything? We had hoses and pumps for forest fire fighting, but no-one was on weekend duty because it wasn't yet summer, and we couldn't get them.''

It wasn't until after the fire had been put out that the true extent of the damage was revealed.

''The top floor was ruined, and the land officer draftsman's records, which were up to 50 years old, were saturated,'' he said.

''The Agriculture Department lost every scrap of paper relating to the activities of the department over a great length of time. And all the plans in the Lands Department, which were highly valuable, were soaked.

"They were stored in horizontal wooden drawers which filled with water. Luckily for our department, we had recently moved a lot of our plans out of a similar system into a vertical metal cabinet, which didn't allow for the accumulation of water.''

urn:contentItem:63FG-RMB1-JD34-V1MF-00000-00Parts of Wombat Forest to reopen soon2021-08-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:04:42ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Parts of Wombat Forest to reopen soonHayley Elg

Parts of the Wombat State Forest will soon reopen to the public after weeks of efforts to clean-up the area after a wild storm swept through the region in June.

Forest Fire Management Victoria have now assessed all of the impacted strategic fire access roads, with about 43 per cent of those roads now cleared.

FFMVic expects this figure to increase during the next five days, with crews to use heavy machinery to remove hazardous trees.

It comes after a ferocious storm ravaged parts of Victoria on June 10, including through the Wombat State Forest, causing hundreds of trees to fall and leaving many residents in towns such as Trentham and Blackwood without power for days.

Some areas of the forest have not yet been cleared due to access issues, seasonal road closures and bad weather.

After further assessments for safety risks and work to address hazardous trees, some areas of the forest will soon be reopened to allow the community to collect firewood, along with some recreational sites.

Grampians Deputy Chief Fire Officer, Tony English, said FFMVic was finalising plans to open parts of the forest.

"Since the storm, our crews have been completing hazardous tree works and stabilising impacted roads and tracks, including allowing access to some designated firewood collection areas from 1 September 2021," he said.

Closures have been in place to protect the community from the continued risk of hazardous trees and due to the movement of heavy machinery conducting clean-up works.

Even when parts of the forest do shortly open, the 'public safety zone' will remain in place and some areas will remain closed.

This is because of ongoing public safety concerns due to the risk of falling trees and as crews will be completing 'critical work' with plant and heavy machinery.

FFMVic stressed the importance of adhering to closures, both for personal safety and to allow crews to operate safely and effectively.

Mr English thanked the community for being patient while the clean-up continued.

Further updates will be provided as more recreation sites reopen.

urn:contentItem:64F0-TS21-JD34-V1JC-00000-00Influx of sea-changers, 'complacency' prompt fire danger warnings2022-01-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:04:41ZLexisNexisInflux of sea-changers, 'complacency' prompt fire danger warningsJessica Greenan

As 15,000 tourists converge on Warrnambool this summer, fire agencies are warning of heightened risk and urged residents to guard against complacency.

With severe heat wave conditions predicted over the New Year period, CFA chief officer Jason Heffernan urged sea-changers heading to the regions to stay updated on fire conditions.

"A wet winter and spring is now behind us and December has been very dry in large parts of Victoria," he said.

"On hot, dry and windy days like the ones we are expecting this weekend, anyone in regional areas of Victoria needs to stay alert to conditions.

"For anyone planning to travel this weekend, it's really important to make sure you know which fire weather district you will be in and travel through.

"You also need to look at the fire danger ratings daily and if it is severe, reconsider your need to travel. Don't travel to areas with an extreme or code red fire danger rating."

IN OTHER NEWS:

Coastal land sale opens door for housing estate

Rates are on the rise again next year

Community stalwart farewelled

Town bounces back after tough run

Can speedway's new year's day specialist o it again?

Forest Fire Victoria spokesman Rod Incoll said holiday-makers posed one of the greatest dangers to regional Victoria including coastal areas like Warrnambool.

"Holiday-makers are one of the greatest hazards because they normally come from an urban area, so often they're basically not fire-wise," he said.

"Most of the country people have some idea of what to do to keep fires safe and when to light them and when not to light them.

"There will be plenty of days in which we can get fires running, it doesn't need to be a big fire that takes a lot of houses - even a small fire that starts in scrub could be quite traumatic for people camping in the area and can destroy their assets."

He said he feared Warrnambool's relatively small history of large-scale bushfires had the potential to also create complacency.

"The fact that there have not been many fire or injuries on the record leads to complacency," he said.

"All you need for a fire is dry fuel and an ignition source.

"Anywhere there's vegetation like coastal scrub is particularly hazardous, especially when you get people who aren't fire-wise who think nothing of having a campfire and then walking away and leaving the site or go to bed in their tent and leave the fire running without ensuring the safety of their fire.

"There's a lot of small stuff that can lead to big stuff."

urn:contentItem:63RB-CC71-F03R-N0V2-00000-00'Yashahime: Princess Half-Demon' Episode 25 Live Stream: How To Watch Online [Spoilers]2021-09-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:04:42ZLexisNexis'Yashahime: Princess Half-Demon' Episode 25 Live Stream: How To Watch Online [Spoilers]

Sep 30, 2021( International Business Times Australia: http://www.ibtimes.com.au/ Delivered by Newstex)
The second act of "Yashahime: Princess Half-Demon" begins in the fall season. Episode 25 of the anime shows Towa, Setsuna and Moroha continuingtheir journey while the threat of Kirinmaru remains active.


The official promo trailer and synopsis of "Yashahime: Princess Half-Demon" Episode 25 are out teasing Towa's vow as she takes up the broken Tenseiga. Setsuna is revived and Towa vows to never put her in any more danger.
Meanwhile, Sesshomaru appears before Towa and hands over the broken Tenseigaand tells her she is capable of putting all her demonic energies into it.
The counterattack of the half-demon sisters is about to begin as they acquire new powers. Can they beat the powerful enemies?
[embedded content]
The second act of the series will also introducea new character named Rion, voiced by Saki Fujita, Anime News Network[1] reported. The ending theme song of theseason is performed by Little Glee Monster.
"Set in feudal Japan, half-demon twins Towa and Setsuna are separated from each other during a forest fire. While desperately searching for her younger sister, Towa wanders into a mysterious tunnel that sends her into present-day Japan, where she is found and raised by Kagome Higurashi's brother, Sota, and his family. Ten years later, the tunnel that connects the two eras has reopened, allowing Towa to be reunited with Setsuna, who is now a demon slayer working for Kohaku. But to Towa's shock, Setsuna appears to have lost all memories of her older sister,"read the official series synopsis, according to Crunchyroll[2].
The cast of "Yashahime: Princess Half-Demon" anime includes Azusa Tadokoro as Moroha, Sara Matsumoto as Towa, Mikako Komatsu as Setsuna, Ai Fairouz as Takechiyo, Kappei Yamaguchi as Inuyasha, Ken Narita as Sesshomaru, Mamiko Noto as Rin, Ryohei Kimura as Kohaku, Takehiro Urao as Hisui, Hitomi Ueda as Gyokuto, Hiroki Yasumoto as Konton, Tsuyoshi Koyama as Hisui, Makoto Yasumura as Miroku, Noriko Hidaka as Spirit of the Tree of Ages, Aya Gomazuru as Kin'u, Asako Dodo as Grammy and Maaya Sakamoto as Zero.
Fans can watch "Yashahime: Princess Half-Demon"[3] Episode 25 online on Crunchyroll and Funimation. The episode will live stream in Japanese with English subtitles this Saturday.

FOREST Fire Management Victoria has announced planned burns to be carried out on Tuesday, January 19, in an area nearby Dimboola - Lochiel rest stop.

The burns will start on January 19 and end on January 26.

Smoke from the burn may be visible from Lochiel rest stop.

The Department of Health and Human Services advises anyone experiencing symptoms of smoke exposure to seek medical advice or contact Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024.

urn:contentItem:62DP-NSR1-JD34-V411-00000-00Stay alert to winter risks: Firefighters2021-04-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:04:42ZLexisNexisStay alert to winter risks: FirefightersElspeth Kernebone

CENTRAL Victorians should remain aware of fire risk into winter despite a quiet summer danger period, firefighters have warned.Greater Bendigo will exit its fire danger period on Monday April 12, at 1am.Country Fire Authority District Two commander Darren Eenjes said 2020-21 had been a quiet fire season, without the extremes of hot weather drying out grassland.Mr Eenjes named fires at Graytown, Kyneton and Moliagul as the major outbreaks of the season, with most other incidents small grass and scrub fires, within one hectare.Mr Eenjes said despite the quiet season, the CFA was still working with Forest Fire Management Victoria on fuel reduction burns to catch the window of opportunity.He said the quiet season meant CFA brigades had time to refresh and recoup after after the 2019-020 season, so they were ready for the winter.Mr Eenjes said District Two was well placed to go into the next fire danger period, but was focusing now on making sure people were safe in the colder months.He urged central Victorians to make sure they checked items such as heaters and electric blankets were functioning properly before use.Mr Eenjes urged people to have their gas flues checked by a qualified tradesperson. He warned the consequences of malfunctioning items could range from a scorch, to a fire that destroyed a home, or even took lives.CFA chief officer Jason Heffernan said autumn and winter were the highest risk periods for residential fires in Victortia, in part due to increased use of home heating.Mr Heffernan reminded people to never leave portable heaters and fireplaces unattended, and to turn heaters off before leaving a room.

He said people should check their heaters were in good working condition, and gas heaters should be professionally serviced every two years.More information about preventing fires in the home is available at: bit.ly/2PLfU5u

urn:contentItem:619B-R031-JD34-V368-00000-00Dozens join ACT RFS after record fire season2020-11-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:04:42ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Dozens join ACT RFS after record fire seasonKatie Burgess

Nearly 60 new firefighters have joined the ACT Rural Fire Service, after the Black Summer bushfires ignited record interest in signing up.

Police and Emergency Services Minister Mick Gentleman on Sunday welcomed 48 new recruits to the service. It brings the number of new rural firefighters this year to 58.

"The recruits have shown great resilience and commitment during their training course, adapting well to new COVID-safe ways of operating to ensure the safety of all service members and the community," Mr Gentleman said.

The ACT Rural Fire Service received hundreds of new volunteer applications after one of the busiest fire seasons on record.

According to the operational review of the season, the ACT declared a record 24 total fire ban days between October and February, compared to around five or six during normal bushfire seasons.

Crews carried out an "impressive numbers of early and extensive deployments interstate" with around 450 ACT rural firefighters serving on a total of 1183 deployments over 2212 days. Then in January, crews fought the Pialligo Redwood Forest fire in Canberra's east and the Orroral Valley fire to the south. ACT Emergency Services Agency Commissioner Georgeina Whelan said volunteers worked tirelessly.

"The 2019-20 bushfire season continually saw how hard our skilled firefighters and support crews work to keep us safe."

urn:contentItem:62TK-68D1-F0J6-J3YS-00000-00Trucks roll out waste2021-06-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:04:42ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8Trucks roll out wasteTaylor Harvey

The first truckloads of waste materials have started rolling out of the illegal waste dump site at Lemon Springs near Kaniva.

Environment Protection Authority Victoria (EPA) estimates around 100 tonnes of waste has already been excavated from the site and taken to appropriately licensed EPA facilities for treatment and disposal.

Last year, EPA used its powers to take control of the site and cleaned it up after the duty holder failed to do so.

Since then, EPA has laid charges against Graham Leslie White for breaches of the Environment Protection Act.

"Given the logistical challenges we face in remediating the site, the progress to date is impressive," EPA Victoria chief executive officer Lee Miezis said following a visit to meet with contractors from EnviroPacific.

"Internal infrastructure to ensure safe handling and management of the excavated waste is in place allowing the removal of the waste to its final destination.

"Safety of the local environment, community, our workforce and contractors is paramount and we are taking all necessary measures."

EPA is working together with the contractors and an Environmental Auditor to determine appropriate additional groundwater well locations, which are scheduled to be installed mid May.

Groundwater will continue to be tested, and the community being updated with the results. The next round of groundwater testing is expected to take place soon.

EPA Victoria are working alongside Grampians Wimmera Mallee Water (GWMWater) to monitor groundwater quality.

CFA together with Forest Fire Management Victoria will be conducting a planned burn along the Kaniva-Edenhope Rd adjacent to the site in the coming weeks.

EPA will be present during the planned burn to advise around safety if access to the site is required. Any queries in relation to the burn should be directed to CFA.

More updates will be provided in the near future, but to stay up-to-date with all the news regarding the illegal dump site, visit: www.epa.vic.gov.au/kaniva

urn:contentItem:5Y21-8XF1-JD3N-5277-00000-00Residents get fire briefing2020-01-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:04:42ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 14Residents get fire briefingGeorgia Holloway

HUNDREDS of concerned residents attended a meeting this week to discuss the fire risk posed by the Ocean Grove Nature Reserve.

Representatives from the CFA, Parks Victoria, Forest Fire Management Victoria and the City of Greater Geelong led the community discussions, with about 250 locals and invested parties gathering at the Shell Road Pavilion on Tuesday after Bellarine MP Lisa Neville called an urgent meeting.

The authorities affirmed their commitment to the mulching program, with another round of fuel reduction set to take place next week.

The mulching and fuel removal program will be funded until June 2020 with no guarantee of additional money due to the demands of higher risk areas such as the Otway Ranges.

Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMV) district manager David Roberts suggested contacting the Aboriginal land owners to conduct a cold burn, however no such practice has been confirmed at this stage.

FFMV chief fire officer Andrew Morrow said it was a great opportunity to meet the public and discuss management of the reserve.

"It was valuable to talk through the benefits and effectiveness of mulching to reduce fuel loads as well as the complexities authorities face managing the reserve given its proximity to homes and businesses," he said.

"We are confident locals can see the benefits of the work already done and what we have planned for the reserve moving forward." While the meeting was thought to be an overall success, there were still some people who left unsatisfied, including resident Geoff Stevens.

"I was very disappointed â€¦ I felt like it was hijacked by others who do not live near the reserve," Mr Stevens said.

He previously voiced his fears that a fire at the reserve could potentially wipe out the town and still believes a fire would be "catastrophic" for those residing nearby.

"Woodlands people are concerned still, I am sure," he said.

"I am talking about our lives here - not property. That can be replaced, our lives cannot be." Senator Sarah Henderson believes that tougher action is required. "The land management failure I witnessed at the Ocean Grove Nature Reserve is completely unacceptable," she said.

"The lack of a concrete plan to reduce fuel loads and the absence of a timetable for any potential future works is concerning, with only minor mulching and fuel removal works funded until June."Ms Henderson has welcomed the Prime Minister's suggestions for a national strategy on hazard reduction.

urn:contentItem:6213-8VX1-JD3N-53JJ-00000-00Otways planned burn to help cut Lorne homes' fire risk2021-02-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:04:41ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8Otways planned burn to help cut Lorne homes' fire risk

FOREST Fire Management Victoria (FFMVic) is set to begin a series of planned burns across the Otway district, including around Lorne, on Wednesday.

More than 200 firefighters, community engagement officers and fuel management specialists will be involved.

The Lorne burning will include two small forested burns to reduce risk for homes on the western edge of the town. Crews will also carry out an ecological grassland burn at Beeac, supporting threatened species in the area.

FFMVic Otway district manager David Roberts said the highest priority planned burns would be in the eastern Otways, due to the number of coastal communities in that area surrounded by dense bushland.

"The upcoming operations will range from small single-day burns near townships to large-scale landscape burns conducted over several days with support from aircraft, numerous- fire tankers and heavy machinery," Mr Roberts said.

Weather permitting, FFMVic will continue with planned burns around Kennedys Creek, Kennett River and Barwon Downs, in forested areas next to communities.

In autumn, FFMVic will look to carry out a cluster of planned burns behind Lorne to connect past planned burns and significantly reduce the speed and intensity of potential bushfires approaching from the north and northwest.

FFMVic is planning to conduct its largest program of planned burning to date around Forrest and Barwon Downs, covering nearly 8000 hectares, in forest around the townships.

The program will also focus on reducing flammable vegetation townships, including Aireys Inlet, Anglesea and Moggs Creek. Find out when and where planned burns are happening at vic.gov.au/plannedburns or by calling 1800 226 226.

urn:contentItem:62DP-NSR1-JD34-V425-00000-00Stay alert to winter risks: Firefighters2021-04-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:04:42ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Stay alert to winter risks: FirefightersElspeth Kernebone

CENTRAL Victorians should remain aware of fire risk into winter despite a quiet summer danger period, firefighters have warned.Greater Bendigo will exit its fire danger period on Monday April 12, at 1am.Country Fire Authority District Two commander Darren Eenjes said 2020-21 had been a quiet fire season, without the extremes of hot weather drying out grassland.Mr Eenjes named fires at Graytown, Kyneton and Moliagul as the major outbreaks of the season, with most other incidents small grass and scrub fires, within one hectare.Mr Eenjes said despite the quiet season, the CFA was still working with Forest Fire Management Victoria on fuel reduction burns to catch the window of opportunity.He said the quiet season meant CFA brigades had time to refresh and recoup after after the 2019-020 season, so they were ready for the winter.Mr Eenjes said District Two was well placed to go into the next fire danger period, but was focusing now on making sure people were safe in the colder months.He urged central Victorians to make sure they checked items such as heaters and electric blankets were functioning properly before use.Mr Eenjes urged people to have their gas flues checked by a qualified tradesperson. He warned the consequences of malfunctioning items could range from a scorch, to a fire that destroyed a home, or even took lives.CFA chief officer Jason Heffernan said autumn and winter were the highest risk periods for residential fires in Victortia, in part due to increased use of home heating.Mr Heffernan reminded people to never leave portable heaters and fireplaces unattended, and to turn heaters off before leaving a room.

He said people should check their heaters were in good working condition, and gas heaters should be professionally serviced every two years.More information about preventing fires in the home is available at: bit.ly/2PLfU5u

urn:contentItem:6186-2Y51-JD3N-52J0-00000-00Ring of fire safety along coast2020-11-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:04:42ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 13Ring of fire safety along coastOlivia Shying

WORK has begun to create 35km of strategic fuel breaks around Lorne, Aireys Inlet and Anglesea to provide better protection from bushfires.

Forest Fire Management Victoria firefighters are using specialist mulching machinery to create the 40m-wide breaks and reduce bushfire fuel.

By connecting existing fuel breaks, the works will create a ring of fuel-reduced land around each town. Crews will remove hazardous trees to allow firefighting within the breaks to be carried out safely.

Work will start this week at Lorne along Allenvale Road, and at Aireys Inlet next week, along Boundary Road.

Senior fuel management officer Bodin Campbell said the new fuel breaks would resemble open parklands following removal of dense ground vegetation, with larger trees left in place.

"The project is about building more fire-resilient towns - improving the ability of our firefighters to control bushfires close to these townships and also to conduct planned burning if required," he said.

"While we've been reducing bushfire fuel on private property for some time, the creation of permanent fuel breaks on private property is a new approach to improve community resilience to the risk of bushfires." Fuel breaks will cross 41 private properties as well as public land. Crews will next week begin removing hazardous trees along 45km of local roadsides, to reduce the risk of falling limbs blocking roads for emergency services and residents.

urn:contentItem:5Y09-H9D1-F0JP-W10B-00000-00Fifth fire victim named2020-01-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:04:42ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8Fifth fire victim namedMONIQUE HORE AND KIERAN ROONEY

A BELOVED grandfather killed on Gippsland's fireground has been named as the fifth victim of Victoria's bushfire disaster.

David Moresi, a Forest Fire Management contractor, died on November 30 in a vehicle rollover at W Tree in East Gippsland.

After supervising bulldozers digging fire breaks, his car rolled as he drove through the fire ground at the end of his shift.

Daughter Kelly Douglass told the Herald Sun her father "would get in to help anyone who needed it".

"He was a really good and caring dad, he loved his grandkids and would do anything for them," she said.

"He always watched them play footy and all of their sports. He would take them camping, motorbike riding and fishing - all the outdoor stuff.

"He would do anything for his family." The 69-year-old and his wife, Judi, had been together since they were 15, and Ms Douglass said the devastated family were "struggling" in the wake of his death.

The former schoolteacher, from Johnsonville, had been due to fly to the Philippines on Boxing Day to help build a school and an annual scholarship for local schoolchildren has now been named in his honour.

Forest Fire Management Victoria chief Chris Hardman said Mr Moresi was a "pillar of the community" and his death had been a tragic blow.

"The many grandchildren, the great bushmen of the future, he taught them all to shoot, fish and hunt," he said.

"We do have a debt that the community can never repay." Mr Hardman yesterday paid tribute to the sacrifice made by Mr Moresi, veteran firefighter Bill Slade and forest management worker Mat Kavanagh, who have all died on duty this fire season.

Buchan man Mick Roberts was also found in his fire-ravaged home, while timber worker Fred Becker suffered a heart attack after defending his and neighbouring properties.

"It's important just to reflect on the significance, the contribution and the sacrifice paid by these people to protect our community," Mr Hardman said.

Emergency Management Victoria Commissioner Andrew Crisp said Mr Moresi's packed funeral showed "the high regard in which he was held". "It was a fitting tribute to a wonderful life." "We all have a role to play, and David's role was as critical as anyone else's in terms of what he was doing to keep our community safe."monique.hore@news.com.au

urn:contentItem:6546-68B1-JD34-V4TC-00000-00Baiting no solution to foxes: MLC2022-04-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:04:42ZLexisNexisCOMMUNITY NEWSPg. 10Baiting no solution to foxes: MLCCaleb Cluff

The sole representative of the Shooters, Fishers and Farmers Party in state parliament says the laying of 1080 fox and vermin bait by the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning in the weeks before duck hunting season leads to more animals being shot.

Jeff Bourmann, who represents Eastern Victoria in the Legislative Council, says the timing of DELWP's decision to use the baits just before the hunting season opened is suspect.

"The timing seems to be very suspect around state game reserves, because they could do it a month earlier, or a month after the season or something like that," Mr Bourmann says.

"The effect on people's dogs would then be basically zero. But they're doing it a week before the season, so there's a lot of people that will quite rightly not take their dog with them, and that will actually lead to more ducks being shot, because the people won't be able to retrieve as many ducks."

Mr Bourmann says using hunters to help reduce fox and feral numbers in state parks and reserves has been raised by his party "time and time again".

"It goes into the deep black hole that is DELWP and common sense - and you may quote me on that," Mr Bourmann says.

"The problem is there's a lot of people in DELWP that are proper environmentalists; they know the best way of getting rid of these pest animals is with a gun and not laying waste to the countryside with poison. But then there's some committed greenie types who are just opposed to hunting. So it just ends up being a disaster area. And it's all the other animals that basically pay the price."

A Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMVic) spokesperson said the agency had been laying baits in Mt Hooghly, Bung Bong and Wareek state forests, to reduce the number of foxes in the area, which prey on nearby livestock as well as native species.

"Risk assessments are undertaken to guide the timing of baiting activities, baiting locations and the placement of baits to ensure there is minimal impact on native animals and other non-target species. Baiting is conducted by a qualified and experienced controller," the spokesperson said.

"Fox baits are buried to a specified depth according to Victorian Directions for Use and manufacturer's guidelines to reduce risks to native animals, which are generally unlikely to uncover buried baits."

The department says 1080 (sodium fluoroacetate) is registered and approved by the Australian Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority (APVMA) for the control of a variety of pest animals in Victoria.

The use of 1080 baits is only one element of pest animal management and is used as part of an integrated pest animal control program. Integrated pest animal control requires planning, the use of a range of control tools and is best achieved with cooperation from adjoining land managers.

FFMVic Senior Forest Manager and Roading Officer Lynda Mabon said the baiting program would run until May 30, 2022.

"Foxes are a pest animal in Australia and attack livestock and wildlife. Every year, foxes are responsible for significant stock losses, especially during lambing season," Ms Mabon said.

"Foxes are also known to carry diseases and increase the spread of weeds in our state forests."

Ms Mabon said baits containing 1080 poison would be buried in bait stations in the program areas, with baits monitored regularly and replaced weekly. The baits will be removed at the end of the program.

"Baits are buried in bait stations according to strict guidelines that minimise the risk of other species taking them," she said.

"These baits could pose a risk to domestic animals and we ask nearby landholders to ensure their dogs and other pets are confined to their property.

"Neighbouring landowners have been notified of the program and signs have been placed at entrances to the control areas so that visitors are aware of the baiting."

Under the Catchment and Land Protection Act 1994, foxes are declared pests.

urn:contentItem:653G-5251-DY19-C4FD-00000-00Smoke from planned burns spurs EPA to warn of ‘very poor' air quality2022-03-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:04:42ZLexisNexisSmoke from planned burns spurs EPA to warn of ‘very poor' air qualityCassandra Morgan

Authorities are warning Melburnians to keep their windows and doors closed on Tuesday, issuing a "very poor" air quality forecast as smoke from burn-offs is expected to drift towards the city.

Authorities are warning Melburnians and residents of central Victoria to keep their windows and doors closed on Tuesday, forecasting "very poor" air quality in the area owing to planned burn-offs across the state.

Victoria's Environment Protection Authority said the city and surrounding central region was likely to experience fair to very poor air quality on Tuesday, noting smoke from planned burns was expected to drift into the area.

Conditions are tipped to be fair in the Latrobe Valley, north-east, south-west and Wimmera regions, and good elsewhere in the state, the authority said.

The "very poor" category is used when air is probably smoky and dusty, and the EPA advises residents to avoid exercising outdoors if they develop a cough or shortness of breath.

Smoke haze hovered over large parts of Victoria on Monday as planned burn-offs continued. Among the worst-affected areas on Monday was Mooroolbark in Melbourne's north-east, which registered "extremely poor" PM10 readings between 10am and 11am.

The air quality at Lilydale was extremely poor at midday, while it was very poor at Dandenong.

Air quality forecast update. Fair to Very Poor air quality is expected today in Melbourne and Central regions. Smoke is drifting from planned burns to the east. Other regions can expect Good to Fair air quality. Visit #AirWatch to see your region: https://t.co/uDkpNZxibR pic.twitter.com/i7YbCIoq7X

— EPA Victoria (@EPA_Victoria) March 28, 2022

The "extremely poor" category, the last rung on the authority's range of air quality measures, demands that people stay indoors as much as possible with their windows and doors closed until the quality gets better, and, if they feel their home is getting uncomfortably smoky, that they consider going to a place with cleaner air if it is safe to do so.

Royal Melbourne Hospital respiratory physician Lou Irving said he expected more hospital admissions on Monday because of the smoke haze.

"In Melbourne, there have been previous studies showing an increase in out-of-hospital cardiac arrest, following times of very poor air quality," Dr Irving told 3AW radio.

Air quality across most of Melbourne was rated good as of about 1.40pm on Monday, while it was fair in locations including Geelong South, Alphington, Brooklyn and Traralgon.

This COMMUNITY INFORMATION - AIR QUALITY
is issued for Eastern Metro.

You will see or smell smoke across parts of Melbourne and surrounding areas.

Smoke is the result of burning from multiple sources including private & planned burns.

Stay informed: https://t.co/ULh5dRimgZ pic.twitter.com/QrpXhdcH4m

— VicEmergency (@vicemergency) March 28, 2022

Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Chris Hardman said crews have done 23 burns across the state since Friday alone and 16 of them were priority burns.

"Autumn is a critical time of year for us to do that planned burning," he told 3AW.

"You wake up in the morning [at] this time of year and you get a dew in the morning. That means that the fuels on the forest floor absorb that moisture so, when we do the ignitions, those fires are not going to escape and become bushfires.

"I do really understand the smoke can be really challenging for people with health conditions and respiratory conditions, so we do monitor the air quality; we work very closely with the EPA."

VicEmergency issued an alert on Monday advising that while there was "no immediate threat to the community", people in Melbourne and surrounds who experienced wheezing, chest tightness and difficulty breathing should call triple zero.

The centralised emergency website said those who were more sensitive to smoke should try to stay indoors, including people with heart or lung conditions, pregnant people, those older than 65 and children under 14.

urn:contentItem:63XT-Y761-JD3N-52DY-00000-00HARSH LESSONS FORGED IN FIRE2021-10-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:04:42ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7HARSH LESSONS FORGED IN FIRELisa Roberts

MISSION ZERO - PUTTING AUSTRALIA FIRST THE Badga Forest fire churned into a mini tornado that ripped without mercy through the valley and ridgelines, annihilating everything in its path.

This firestorm was a mad beast that was so large it was creating its own weather patterns. It roared and howled, and it picked up everything we had built with our bare hands, swallowed it up, and threw it around.

Seeing the once pristine and lush landscape's ecology, inhabitants and wildlife completely savaged is heartbreaking. It now sits eerily -silent, raped and desolate.

Wandella was a place full of life where we have grown living things for 20 years.

We built our home and business from scratch - with no money, no buildings, and no power or water at the outset. But it had soul.

Our team loved working there in a workplace that was like no other. Our kids and friends had fantastic adventures playing along the creek, swimming in the dam, building cubbies, getting dirty, making art from found objects, and breathing in real life in nature.

Our totally self-sustaining property was completely off the grid and we had dedicated our business to making a positive impact on the planet, practising what we preach in our own back yard, and making efforts to minimise our carbon footprint.

It's not so much the buildings and "stuff" that is painful to lose. It's the dreams and experiences that we created there. So now we are back to where we started - with no power, water, phone, internet, buildings or facilities.

Working on and in the landscape in the ACT and NSW for the past 30 years means that we have become palpably aware of a changed and changing climate.

This raging inferno was of proportions unexpected, and it's critical to rethink how we individually and collectively deal with these new and destructive forces of nature.

Our team have been facing horrendous weather conditions working on project sites, and it's time we - the public, the designers, and the government - think more cleverly about how we work and the work that we are doing.

We must plan and construct buildings and landscapes more appropriately, as current practice will not be future-proof.

We must restore our landscapes and make smarter choices about how we treat and use our planet's natural resources.

We must take personal responsibility for our part in all this and take action in our own lives. And we must speak up about our changed climate and why these fires were so ferocious - because the -science doesn't lie.

Lisa Roberts is a bushfire survivor whose home and business in the Bega Valley was wiped out by the Black Summer fires of 2019-20

urn:contentItem:616T-8J31-DY66-54C6-00000-00Land clearing plan to save coastal towns from bushfires2020-11-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:04:42ZLexisNexisLand clearing plan to save coastal towns from bushfires

Document links may not lead to an active page. Page maintenance is at the discretion of the publisher.

Chad Van Estrop

More than 100 hectares of land around Lorne, Aireys Inlet and Anglesea will be kept free of fuel for bush fires under a $1.5 million state government spend.

Planned burns, mulching and slashing will take place in rings around the towns to create fire breaks along existing tracks.

The state government said the 40m wide breaks would go through some private land and owners would be consulted by Forest Fire Management Victoria and the Surf Coast Shire Council.

Some of the fuel break will be created this year to show each township what they look like, and all works are expected to be completed by early next year.

The sate government said it is planning how to expand the project to other coastal towns.

Meanwhile, Regional Roads Victoria will complete hazardous tree removal along 45km of roadside from Torquay to Lorne, and along the Lorne-Deans Marsh Road.

Environment Minister Lily D'Ambrosio said the work would improve safety for fire crews.

"With the safe window to conduct planned burning getting smaller, practical on-ground initiatives like this are vital to make sure we continue to reduce risk in what is a very bushfire prone landscape," Minister D'Ambrosio said.

urn:contentItem:62PT-K181-F0J6-J055-00000-00Planned burns to happen across the Wimmera in May2021-05-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:04:42ZLexisNexisPlanned burns to happen across the Wimmera in May

Forest Fire Management Victoria will be conducting several planned burns across the Wimmera this month.

On Wednesday, May 19, two fuel reduction burns will be conducted; a 79ha burn at Jilpanger - Lake Coyrahilla and a 269ha burn on Tallageria - Haebichs Road.

The burns will take place between 12pm and 6pm.

On May 21, a 12ha fuel reduction burn will take place at Lake Ratzcastle campground between 12pm and 6pm.

A 12ha fuel reduction burn will also take place on Salisbury South Road.

Two burns will take place on Sunday, May 23; a 5000ha burn on Little Desert - McCabes Hut Track and a 51ha burn on Arapiles - Centenary Park Road.

On Monday, May 24 a 276ha burn will be conducted on Little Desert - Eagle Swamp Track between 12pm and 6pm.

Smoke may be visible from the Little Desert National Park, Arapiles, Salisbury Bushland Reserve, Tallageria Nature Conservation Reserve and Jilpanger Nature Conservation Reserve.

What to do about:

SMOKE:

If you are experiencing any symptoms that may be due to smoke exposure, the Department of Health and Human Services advises that you should seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024.

Close windows and doors to prevent smoke from entering.

ROADS:

Road travel may be hazardous due to low visibility associated with smoke.

Signs may be in place to slow traffic. Obey all traffic signs and instructions from fire agency crews near the burn.

For travel times and roadworks check http://traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.

ACCESS TO FOREST/ PARK RECREATION SITES:

Be aware of planned burns happening in your local area and stay clear of areas where burns are taking place or areas that have recently been burnt.

Access to walking tracks, car parks, camping grounds and picnic sites in areas close to or in burn areas may be restricted.

Stay informed about planned burning:

Visit our website at plannedburns.ffm.vic.gov.au

Sign up for automated notifications about planned burns near you via plannedburns.ffm.vic.gov.au

Callers who are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment can contact via the National Relay Service on 1800 555 677.

urn:contentItem:6293-13F1-JD34-V1T4-00000-00Upgrades for runway2021-03-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:04:41ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Upgrades for runwayCassandra Langley

A much-needed upgrade to the Horsham Aerodrome will deliver work for five Wimmera-based companies in the coming months.

The works will be conducted after a Civil Aviation Safety Authority review of the airport's suitability to provide essential services including aeromedical transfers.

The major upgrades will ensure the facility can continue to provide modern emergency services into the future.

Works include runway pavement reconstruction, new guidance lighting and the installation of a new backup power generator.

Existing air services will continue to operate during the works.

Horsham Rural City Council mayor Robyn Gulline said the $211,000 upgrade would improve the airport's usability under a range of conditions.

"There's a backup power source there now which provides emergency power to parts of the aerodrome," Cr Gulline said.

But critically, the new generator will be large enough to power all of the runway lights and the aeromedical transfer services at the same time.

"New lighting will ensure the runway can be seen from further away for all approaches.

"And the reconstruction of the runway surface will resolve some grading issues at the northern end, and in turn, make the aerodrome more safe."

The aerodrome is used by general aviation and the local aero club, two gliding clubs, crop dusting firms, charter aircraft, air ambulances, as well as a Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning air base to support the efforts of fire-fighters - through Forest Fire Management Victoria - and occasional military aircraft.

The upgrades to the facility were made possible after Horsham Rural City Council successfully applied for $105,591 in Federal Government funding, which was announced last year.

The Horsham Rural City Council has matched the grant dollar for dollar.

"We are grateful to the Australian Government for its contribution under the regional airports funding program," Cr Gulline said.

urn:contentItem:5Y87-83N1-F0NT-H3RD-00000-00Public servants who fought bushfires left waiting for payment2020-02-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:04:42ZLexisNexisPublic servants who fought bushfires left waiting for paymentABSTRACT

Victorian public servants who recently helped fight fires have not yet been paid the entitlements earned over summer.

FULL TEXT

Victorian public servants who recently helped fight fires have not yet been paid the entitlements earned over summer due to a "significant number of timesheets being processed".

The employees expect they will not receive the funds for several months.

The Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning reportedly said there had been a hold up with processing payments, but assured workers -- including Forest Fire Management Victoria employees -- that they would be paid.

"[Forest Fire Management Victoria] staff who have worked on the bushfires will be paid their allowances and overtime as required under their workplace agreement," a departmental spokesperson told The Age.

"Given the exceptionally busy season, with staff working multiple deployments and rotations, there are a significant number of timesheets being processed, which has resulted in some delays in processing payments. We are working hard to process outstanding payments as quickly as possible and thank staff for their patience."

The Victorian branch of the Community and Public Sector Union has condemned the mishap.

"Payment delays are unacceptable when these workers have spent their summer fighting fires and protecting Victorians," CPSU state secretary Karen Batt said.

"Many are based in Gippsland and have lost homes and personal belongings to fire. It's a straightforward computer-based payroll and the data providing the pay boost should have been pre-organised and pre-loaded."

  https://twitter.com/CPSU_Vic/status/1229736164547973121

Batt argued cuts to the Victorian Public Service meant departments "simply don't have enough staff" to process the payments, and acknowledged Treasurer Tim Pallas'   plans to shave $4 billion from the state budget, which would mostly come from the public service.

"You can imagine how bad it's going to end up once Treasury cuts $4 billion. There won't be anyone employed to pay the workforce. God forbid if MP's were to miss being paid their allowances and higher duties," she said.

The union noted that some employees owed money from the 2018-2019 fire season were not paid until May -- months after the fires had ended.

This fire season has seen more than 3500 state public servants help fight fires and assist with rescue and recovery efforts. Three have died during the bushfires.

The CPSU last month requested a good faith payment be made to members as "many are involved fighting bushfires and or assisting communities affected including our precious fauna".

urn:contentItem:5Y91-HCY1-JD6R-T2BS-00000-00Public servants who fought bushfires left waiting for payment2020-02-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:04:42ZLexisNexisPublic servants who fought bushfires left waiting for paymentABSTRACT

Victorian public servants who recently helped fight fires have not yet been paid the entitlements earned over summer.

FULL TEXT

Victorian public servants who recently helped fight fires have not yet been paid the entitlements earned over summer due to a "significant number of timesheets being processed".

The employees expect they will not receive the funds for several months.

The Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning reportedly said there had been a hold up with processing payments, but assured workers -- including Forest Fire Management Victoria employees -- that they would be paid.

"[Forest Fire Management Victoria] staff who have worked on the bushfires will be paid their allowances and overtime as required under their workplace agreement," a departmental spokesperson told The Age.

"Given the exceptionally busy season, with staff working multiple deployments and rotations, there are a significant number of timesheets being processed, which has resulted in some delays in processing payments. We are working hard to process outstanding payments as quickly as possible and thank staff for their patience."

The Victorian branch of the Community and Public Sector Union has condemned the mishap.

"Payment delays are unacceptable when these workers have spent their summer fighting fires and protecting Victorians," CPSU state secretary Karen Batt said.

"Many are based in Gippsland and have lost homes and personal belongings to fire. It's a straightforward computer-based payroll and the data providing the pay boost should have been pre-organised and pre-loaded."

  https://twitter.com/CPSU_Vic/status/1229736164547973121

Batt argued cuts to the Victorian Public Service meant departments "simply don't have enough staff" to process the payments, and acknowledged Treasurer Tim Pallas'   plans to shave $4 billion from the state budget, which would mostly come from the public service.

"You can imagine how bad it's going to end up once Treasury cuts $4 billion. There won't be anyone employed to pay the workforce. God forbid if MP's were to miss being paid their allowances and higher duties," she said.

The union noted that some employees owed money from the 2018-2019 fire season were not paid until May -- months after the fires had ended.

This fire season has seen more than 3500 state public servants help fight fires and assist with rescue and recovery efforts. Three have died during the bushfires.

The CPSU last month requested a good faith payment be made to members as "many are involved fighting bushfires and or assisting communities affected including our precious fauna".

urn:contentItem:60V4-F5F1-DYG0-900W-00000-00VIC:Crisp to front Vic hotel quarantine probe2020-09-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:04:42ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVIC:Crisp to front Vic hotel quarantine probeMELBOURNE Sept 15

  Emergency Management Commissioner Andrew Crisp is set to give evidence to Victoria's hotel quarantine inquiry.
   Mr Crisp signed off on the decision to use private security guards for hotel quarantine on March 27, just hoursbefore the first returning overseas travellers began arriving in Victoria.


   He hasmaintained the Australian Defence Force didn't offer personnel for the program at the meeting, nor did he ask for their help.
   The inquiry, headed by retired judge Jennifer Coate, has previously heard the Department of Jobs, Precincts and Regions was responsible for awarding contracts to three security companies - MSS, Unified and Wilson.
   About 99 per cent of Victoria's second COVID-19 wave can be traced to three outbreaks at the Rydges on Swanston and Stamford Plaza hotels.
   In late May, when the virus first broke out of the hotels, 19 people in Victoria had died from COVID-19. The state's death toll is now 729.
   Chris Eagle from Forest Fire Management Victoria will also appear at the inquiry on Tuesday.
   The inquiry has previously heard Mr Eagle was one of the key people involved in the program's day-to-day management.
   Premier Daniel Andrews confirmed on Sunday he would appear before the inquiry on September 23.

urn:contentItem:64PF-T581-F0J6-J25X-00000-00Firefighters' plea after 'completely avoidable' fires2022-02-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:04:42ZLexisNexisSATURDAYPg. 4Firefighters' plea after 'completely avoidable' firesHayley Elg

Firefighters are urging the community to exercise extreme caution if it is deemed absolutely necessary to use equipment, after two significant fires in the region this week.

The first burned through 100-hectares as it moved towards Beaufort on Wednesday morning, while the second ignited near the Western Highway at Burrumbeet on Friday afternoon.

With a two-kilometre perimeter around the fire, it burned through 30-hectares before it was brought under control.

District 16's Assistant Chief Fire Officer, Bernie Fradd, said both were caused by people operating slashers and were therefore both preventable.

"There is a real urgency for people to pay attention to make sure they are not the person who causes a fire that gets away and destroys homes, stock, property and lives."

These incidents have come as firefighters in nearby districts have also responded to fires caused by mowing and slashing operations.

He said fires that were the result of carelessness were "very frustrating" for volunteer firefighters, who gave up their time to respond, especially when there were other incidents to respond to that could not be predicted.

"These fires shouldn't have happened. We want people to consider whether the work they are doing is absolutely necessary. Anyone who is operating any machinery in long grass at the moment, including driving a car, needs to be aware that they're likely to cause a fire."

Praising the work of firefighters, ACFO Fradd said there had been an "enormous amount of resources" put into the two fires this week.

The Beaufort fire required dozens of firefighters working on more than 30 fire trucks as well as fire bomber aircraft, in addition to support from Forest Fire Management Victoria and the council.

Meanwhile, the Burrumbeet fire resulted in dark gray plumes of smoke billowing across the area and the highway being closed for a short time.

Bringing it under control also required significant resources - 10 fire trucks, several field command vehicles, air support as well as police.

Aside from the initial emergency response, the fires require monitoring in the days afterwards to ensure every single ember has been extinguished so it does not reignite in windy conditions.

He said work to prepare properties for the fire season should have long been completed and no permits to burn-off would be issued for at least four or five weeks.

"It is very dry out there now so it is time for the community to pay attention to what they're doing, because our volunteer firefighters cannot keep up this pace for the next six weeks," ACFO Fradd said. "It is very draining for them."

"If you're considering works you need to consider if you can control a fire if one starts. If you are doubting if you can, the safest thing to do is to hold off until we've had some rain and it's a lot safer to do."

But if property owners deem it absolutely necessary to complete work now, he said it was "critical" to ensure fire suppression equipment was at hand.

This equipment includes extinguishers and a pump connected to enough water.

Equipment should be well maintained before use, while the likelihood of equipment hitting a rock and sparking a fire should also be considered.

Police are notified for investigation if a fire is deemed to be recklessly lit, with the potential for charges to be laid.

"We have little sympathy around these types of fires because they are completely avoidable."

urn:contentItem:61V9-7TP1-F0J6-J1T5-00000-00fire2021-01-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:04:42ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4fireHayley Elg

Emergency services are on alert in case a fire breaks out during the current heatwave, which is set to peak on Monday.

The Country Fire Authority's District 15 Duty Officer, Mark Verdoorn, said that due to the rainfall during spring and the resulting grass growth that has since begun to cure the concern was a fast-running grass fire. While the fire danger rating was classified as 'high' on Sunday, it will be 'very high' on Monday, though Mr Verdoorn said it was pushing into the 'severe' category.

Emergency services are prepped to rapidly respond to a fire, with numerous control centres to be operational. This includes the Incident Control Centre - which sees representatives from agencies including CFA, Victoria Police, Forest Fire Management Victoria and local councils - which will be up and running in Sebastopol from 10am.

Mr Verdoorn urged residents to ensure their fire plans are prepared in case a grass fire was to ignite, as they move much faster than a bushfire. If living in an urban fringe area close to open grasslands and a fire breaks out and it is too late to leave, the advice is to walk - not drive - at least two streets back. With thick smoke produced from grass fires that could pose a risk while driving, it also means the roads will not be congested and emergency vehicles will be able to reach the fire as quickly as possible.

As many people have taken a long weekend, Mr Verdoorn said there was a concern about the number of campers in regional Victoria. While a total fire ban has not declared for the area on Monday, he still urged people to consider not lighting a campfire, but if it is completely necessary then to ensure it is completely extinguished before leaving a site.

urn:contentItem:64NY-14J1-JBN5-F12R-00000-00Logging, bushfires hamper beekeepers' ability to satisfy increasing pollination demand2022-02-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:04:42ZLexisNexisLogging, bushfires hamper beekeepers' ability to satisfy increasing pollination demandBy Peter Somerville

A beekeeper thinks bush management practices will mean there will be "no value for decades" in some Gippsland forests, which could slow an industry's growth.

Gippsland beekeepers fear they are not being heard in forest management discussions, and as a result, some patches of the forest will have "no value for decades".

That's the concern of Ian Cane, a third-generation beekeeper who has been involved in the industry for most of his life.

He said some parts of the bush that were logged and then hit by the Black Summer bushfires had suffered major structural changes.

He described two different types of structural change, one of which was when the bush that grew back after logging was significantly different to what went before it. 

Standing in a regenerating coupe [area of logged trees] that had burnt, Mr Cane said some parts of the bush undergo a secondary structural change, where the regrowing bush is damaged by fire.

"The regen here was 10 years old and has been killed by the wildfire because it's young," he said.

"What should normally happen in these forests is that epicormic shoots would come out and those trees would then develop again and away they'd go."

He said because the fire had been so intense it had killed all the regrowth in this here.

"After the fire, there was literally nothing left except these black sticks but as a last resort, a survival mechanism, these trees are shooting out a number of shoots," he said.

"So, now you've got a multi-stem forest, so a major structural change."

Pressure mounts on beekeepers

There is an increasing demand for beekeepers' pollination services, but Mr Cane said deteriorated coupes make it harder to meet the demand.

"If you introduce fire into this coupe (again), it will be another 40 years maybe 60 years to be of any value at all to our industry.

He said It could be an incredible amount of time that it would never repair itself to a state that it buds, flowers and seeds.

Some good work

However, Mr Cane stressed he and many beekeepers were not opposed to logging and timber industries and pointed out a coupe that he believed had been harvested and managed well.

"Certainly as an industry, we're multi-use, multi-value, but we must protect those uses in perpetuity. It's the methodology in which it's harvested that we must get right."

He said the industry had worked with VicForests to develop harvesting prescriptions and to ensure value for all.

"We've always had pretty much a place around the table and as an industry. I think we've done very well. But I don't say the outcomes match that.

"We've worked with VicForests over the time and that's really led to nowhere. We've developed harvesting prescriptions with VicForests and to our great disappointment that hasn't achieved anything."

Feedback welcome

VicForests said consulting with the beekeeping industry was an important part of its planning process in East Gippsland and it welcomed feedback.

"We also follow the Gippsland Forest Apiary Plan, which adds further protection to retaining a  viable area of forest trees important to bees," a spokesperson said.

"VicForests also assists the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning in the recovery of forests following the 2019/20 bushfires through the Victorian government's reseeding programs for areas impacted by consecutive fires and is also involved in bushfire risk management as a member of Forest Fire Management Victoria."
